office:text.text:p: BULGARIAN ACADEMY OF SCIENCES
Software Reliability of the Computer Systems in the Light of Revolution 4.0
Nikolay Petrov*, Todor Balabanov**, Ivan Petrov***
* Faculty of Engineering and Pedagogy of Sliven - Technical University of Sofia
** Institute of Information and Communication Technologies - Bulgarian Academy of Sciences
*** Paysafe Group, Sofia, Bulgaria
Emails: nikipetrov_1953@abv.bg todorb@iinf.bas.bg ivan.petrov@paysafe.com

text:span.text:span: together areas which are not normally classified as an industry. It concerns machines with wireless data transfer, sensors that can

the entire production line and make decisions on its own. The core are automation and data exchange in manufacturing technologies and processes. In such progressive expansion of technologies the reliability of the software components becomes a critical aspect

office:text.text:p: 1. Introduction

text:p.text:span: reliability is that the ideal objects in man, nature and society are not perfect.

he quality of their conformity to material things is not absolute and vice versa. It follows that there may be a time when an ideal object is in poor conformity. If we define that moment, phenomenon, or event as object rejection, the term "conceptual object reliability" or "conceptual reliability" becomes meaningful. It is important for the development of reliability because linking reliability with the quality of compliance is the second direction for developing the concept of "reliability", since in complex systems we have abandoned the concept of "failure" because of the possibility of redundancy

office:text.text:p: An objective substantive reason for the reliability of conceptual objects is the presence of errors in the created software object, which is why the realized quality of compliance does not always meet the expected (predicted).

From the point of view of the reliability of a conceptual object, the software is characterized as follows: any software product, with strictly fixed input data and absolutely reliable equipment, is executed by a strictly defined algorithm and connection at the call point. However, the combinatorial nature and random change of input data, accumulated information and the large number of conditional transitions create many different branches of the overall computing information and communication process that cannot be fully verified (some of them are unlikely to be implemented due to the low probability of the corresponding combination of input).

As a result, the "side effect" phenomenon known in the software appears. A side effect is understood to be different results from the execution of the same software product or module, with the same input parameters. In both cases, this is called software failure. For software support, failure may also be self-eliminating, in which the transition from incapacity to work is done without outside interference and for a very short time. Such a self-defeating failure has already been defined as a failure [2,3].

Reliability of software is its ability to deliver predicted (expected) outputs whenever inputs meet specifications. The definition belongs to Glenford Myers [1]. The reliability of the software is thus determined by: 1) distortion of input information, 2) undetected bugs in the code, 3) the quality of the operator's work with the software and the training opportunity, 4) attack by viral agents and others.
The first two cases mentioned above do not express the intrinsic property of the software, but rather are its function. Here is the fine difference between objective and conceptual reliability.

As an important difference in the definition of a self-repair failure entity operator error, a software fault is any situation of endless cycles in runtime that makes it impossible to complete a function in the software itself. Software failure is an error (including distorted input).
2. Model for growing the reliability of software

Тhis document is a template for Microsoft Word versions 6.0 or later. If you are reading a paper version of this document, please download the electronic file, CITJournal.doc. Please, do not put any running header/footer or page number in the submitted paper.

text:list-item.text:p: If using Numbering or Bullets, use NumberingCIT, or BulletsCIT case.
If using Numbering or Bullets, use NumberingCIT, or BulletsCIT case.

office:text.text:p: You can type over sections of CITJournal.doc or Copy formats from this document or cut and paste from another document and then use markup styles. The pull-down style menu is at the left of the Formatting Toolbar at the top of your Word window (for example, the style at this point in the document is “Text”). Highlight a section that you want to designate with a certain style, and then select the appropriate name on the style menu. The style will adjust your fonts and line spacing. Do not change the font sizes or line spacing to squeeze more text into the limited number of pages. Use italics for emphasis; do not underline.

CIT will not do any final formatting of your paper. Your manuscript should be “camera-ready”. Pages limit is 20 pages for scientific papers, 32 pages for surveys, 12 pages for application papers,. Please, do not modify the margins as listed in Table 1.
1.1. A subsection Subtitles level 2, 3, …: Size 11, not capitalize each word, spacing Before 12 pt, After 6 pt. May be numbered (or use Subtitle2CIT case for Subtitles level 2, 3, …).

Page margins: All dimensions are in centimeters. Size A4, margins mirrored. It is very important to maintain these margins. They are necessary to put information and page numbers of CIT journal by the publishing department of IICT.
Table 1. Page margins
1.2. Figures and tables

All figures must be embedded in the document. When you include the image, make sure to insert the actual image rather than a link to your local computer. The figures must not be wider than 12 cm. Insert by Picture tools, Text wrapping – inline with text, on a separate line, centred. The labels under figures must start by Fig. No (subsequent number of the Fig.) – in Times New Roman font, size 9 pt, centred.

Figure axis labels are often a source of confusion. Use words rather than symbols. As an example, write the quantity “Magnetization,” or “Magnetization M,” not just “M”. Put units in parentheses. Do not label axes only with units. As in Fig. 1, for example, write “Magnetization (A/m)” or “Magnetization (Am1),” not just “A/m.” Do not label axes with a ratio of quantities and units. For example, write “Temperature K”, not “Temperature/K”.

text:p.text:span: Multipliers can be especially confusing. Write “Magnetization (kA/m)” or “Magnetization (103 A/m).” Do not write “Magnetization (A/m)

1000” because the reader would not know whether the top axis label in Fig. 1 meant 16000 A/m or 0.016 A/m. Figure labels should be legible, 9 point type, centered, no dot mark at the end; spacing before 6 pt, after 6 pt.

text:span.text:span: Fig. 1. Bifurcation: Plot of local maxima of x with damping a decreasing

office:text.text:p: The text in the tables must be Times New Roman, size 9 pt, in Table Properties set alignment Centre, text wrapping – none.
The labels above the tables must start with Table No (subsequent number of the table), size 9 pt, spacing before 6 pt, after 6 pt, the text remaining only above the table, not wider.
Table 2. The identification results
2. Procedure for paper submission
2.1. Review stage

Please, use this document as a “template” to prepare your manuscript. For submission guidelines, follow instructions on paper submission system, as well as on IICT website http://www.cit.iit.bas.bg/cit_inst_authors.html.
2.2. Final stage

Authors are expected to mind the margins diligently. If your manuscript bleeds into margins, you will be required to resubmit and delay the proceedings preparation in the process. The paper will be published on IICT website and in “Cybernetics and Information Technologies” journal.
3. Math

You will be using Word. Use either Microsoft Equation Editor for equations in your paper (Insert | Object | Object | Microsoft Equation 3). “Float over text” should not be selected. If brief and simple, the formulas may be written as math variables within the text line (the variables being Italic). Use symbols with the help of “Insert symbol” and superscript and subscript of the font.
Number equations consecutively with equation numbers in parentheses flush with the left margin, as in (1).

text:p.text:span: Be sure that the symbols in your equation have been defined before the equation appears or immediately following. Italicize symbols (
might refer to temperature, but T is the unit Tesla and also T used for a
). Refer to “(1),” not “Eq. (1)” or “equation (1),” except at the beginning of a sentence: “Equation (1) is …”

office:text.text:p: 4. Units

Use SI as primary units. Other units may be used as secondary units (in parentheses). This applies to papers in data storage. For example, write “15 Gb/cm2 (100 Gb/in2)”. An exception is when English units are used as identifiers in trade, such as “3.5 in disk drive.” Avoid combining SI and CGS units, such as current in amperes and magnetic field in oversets. This often leads to confusion because equations do not balance dimensionally. If you must use mixed units, clearly state the units for each quantity in an equation.
5. Conclusion

A conclusion section is not required. Although a conclusion may review the main points of the paper, do not replicate the abstract as the conclusion. A conclusion might elaborate on the importance of the work or suggest applications and extensions.
